info.description: > Join our Ecosystem and build your own Apps!The Sikka Ecosystem harnesses the power of over 50 unique apps. > Visit : [Sikka Marketplace](https://www.sikkasoft.com) > Note : Certain special characters are not allowed in the API URI path segment (:, #, ?, /, \\, %, +, =) #### what is new in API v4 ? | Features | v2 | v4 | | --- | --- | --- | | Base url | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2) | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4) | | Auth url | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/auth/v2](https://api.sikkasoft.com/auth/v2) | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4) | | API field filtering | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Expanding object | 🗸 | ⨯ | | Pagination | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Rate limiting | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Modified records | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Practice events | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Output format | /json ( Default )/xml | json | | HTTP compression | Accept-Encoding: gzip,compress | Accept-Encoding: gzip,compress | | Error codes | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Request header | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Response header | 🗸 | 🗸 ( with more info. headers) | | Request key | In query parameter : request_key In request header : Request-Key | (Not recommended) In query parameter : request_key (Recommended) In request header : Request-Key | | Webhooks | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Practice Query language ( PQL ) | 🗸 | ⨯ | | Date format | YYYY-MM-DD , YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS | YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS | | Query functions | AND | AND,OR,LIKE,GREATER THAN,LESS THAN,EQUAL TO,NOT EQUAL TO | | Query filter syntax | & | \- find=`api field name`\=eq_`value` , =eq_ → equal to , =neq_ → not equal to , =like_ → like , =gt → greater than ( supports int & date ) , =gte → greater than equal to ( supports int & date ) , =lt → less than ( supports int & date ) , =lte → less than equal to ( supports int & date ) , find=patient_id=eq_23::OR::guarantor_id=neq_45 , find=patient_id=eq_23::AND::amount=gt_45 | | | | | | Response body | All fields by default | In v4 , by default few api fields will be return and if user wants more fields then it can be fetched by “field” parameters. This feature has been implemented to improve api response time & return only necessary fields in API response. | | | | | | Query parameters | predefined | Result will be filtered by any fields returned in API response | | HATEOAS ( hrefs ) | 🗸 | 🗸 | | Generate request key | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/start?app_id=app_id&app_key=app_key&office_id=office_id&secret_key=secret_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/start?app_id=app_id&app_key=app_key&office_id=office_id&secret_key=secret_key) | POST [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key) | | Generate request key using refresh key | ⨯ | POST [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key) | | Delete refresh key | DELETE [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/refresh_token/{refresh_token}?client_id={client_id}&client_secret={client_secret}](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/refresh_token/{refresh_token}?client_id={client_id}&client_secret={client_secret}) | DELETE [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/refresh_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/refresh_key) -Header refresh-key:"" app-id:"" app-key:"" | | End API | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/end?request_key={request_key}](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/end?request_key={request_key}) | DELETE [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key) -Header Request-Key:"" |

item.name: Quickstart
item.description:
In this guide we will walk you through all necessary steps to start accessing data from practice.

  

1.Authorized practices:

  

This API will give you the list of practices from which you can access data

```javascript

GET https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/authorized_practices HTTP/1.1
Host: api.sikkasoft.com
app-id: <application id>
app-key: <application key>

```

  

* Collect 'office_id' and 'secret_key'

  

2.POST request_key API call:
API to get Request Key for practices:

  

In response of ‘authorized_practices’ API you have ‘office_id’ and ‘secret_key’. Use it in POST request_key API
```javascript
POST https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key
Body
{
"grant_type":"request_key",
"office_id":"",
"secret_key":""
"app_id":"app_id",
"app_key":"app_key"
}
```
Response
```javascript
{
"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key_info?request_key=xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
"request_key": "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
"start_time": "2020-09-23T04:00:28",
"end_time": "2020-09-24T04:00:28",
"expires_in": "85603 second(s)",
"issued_to": "D20006",
"status": "active",
"request_count": "1",
"scope": "start,end,appointment_statuses",
"domain": "Dental",
"refresh_key":"xxxx"
}  
```
* Collect 'request_key'

3.Patients API call:
API to get the list of patients

```javascript

https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients
Host: api.sikkasoft.com 
request-key:  <request_key>
```
More information about a particular endpoints are in API’s documentation , which includes query parameters the API will accept.

item.name: Authorization
Generate request_key
item.description:
```
POST https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key
Header: Content-Type:applicaion/json
Body:
{
"grant_type":"request_key/refresh_key",[required]
"office_id":"",[required if grant_type=request_key.Get it from authorized_practices API]
"secret_key":"",[required if grant_type=request_key.Get it from authorized_practices API]
"refresh_key":"",[required if grant_type=refresh_key]
"app_id":"app_id",[required]
"app_key":"app_key"[required]
}
```
✅ "grant_type" must be either "request_key" or "refresh_key"
 
###### Request for create new request_key
```
POST https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key
Header: Content-Type:applicaion/json
Body:
{
"grant_type":"request_key",
"office_id":"office_id",
"secret_key":"secret_key",
"app_id":"app_id",
"app_key":"app_key"
}
```
Response:
In response you will get 'request_key' along with other details like request end time , expires_in , for office_id that request_key issued to , scope etc.
```
{
    "href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key_info?request_key=4d74aaaxxxx22b",
    "request_key": "4d74aaaxxxx22b",
    "start_time": "2020-09-23T04:00:28",
    "end_time": "2020-09-24T04:00:28",
    "expires_in": "85603 second(s)",
    "issued_to": "D20006",
    "status": "active",
    "request_count": "1",
    "scope": "start,end,appointment_statuses,appointments,claims,clinical_conditions,contact_details,data_check,dental_patients,drugs,employee,fee_schedules,guarantors,insurance_accounts,insurance_accounts_receivables,insurance_companies,insurance_company_details,insurance_estimate,insurance_plan_coverage,lab_panels,lab_results,medical_notes,patient_charts,patient_conditions,patient_statuses,patients,payment_plans,payment_types,practices,procedure_codes,providers,request_keys,transactions,treatment_plan_statuses,treatment_plans,applications,authorized_practices,pms_list,request_keys,request_keys_details,POST practice_query",
    "domain": "Dental",
"refresh_key":"xxxxxxxxx"
}
```

item.name: Refresh token
item.description:
Request_keys expire 24 hours after they are issued. The refresh token can be used to make a request for a new request_key, similar to the initial access token exchange. Refresh tokens don’t expire until you delete refresh token.

Request
```
POST https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key
Header: Content-Type:applicaion/json
Body:
{
"grant_type":"refresh_key",
"app_id":"app_id",
"app_key":"app_key"
}
```
Response:
```
{
    "href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key_info?request_key=4d74aaaxxxx22b",
    "request_key": "4d74aaaxxxx22b",
    "start_time": "2020-09-23T04:00:28",
    "end_time": "2020-09-24T04:00:28",
    "expires_in": "85603 second(s)",
    "issued_to": "D20006",
    "status": "active",
    "request_count": "1",
    "scope": "start,end,appointment_statuses,appointments,claims,clinical_conditions,contact_details,data_check,dental_patients,drugs,employee,fee_schedules,guarantors,insurance_accounts,insurance_accounts_receivables,insurance_companies,insurance_company_details,insurance_estimate,insurance_plan_coverage,lab_panels,lab_results,medical_notes,patient_charts,patient_conditions,patient_statuses,patients,payment_plans,payment_types,practices,procedure_codes,providers,request_keys,transactions,treatment_plan_statuses,treatment_plans,applications,authorized_practices,pms_list,request_keys,request_keys_details,POST practice_query",
    "domain": "Dental",
"refresh_key":"xxxxxxxxx"
}
```

item.name: Revoking tokens
item.description:
If you want to delete request_key or refresh_key

#### Delete request_key
```
Delete https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key
Header:  
Content-Type:applicaion/json  
Request-Key:"xxxxxxx"
```
Response:
```
{
    "http_code": "200",
    "http_code_desc": "OK",
    "error_code": "API0002",
    "short_message": "OK",
    "long_message": "Request Session terminated successfully.",
    "more_information": ""
}
```

item.name: Delete refresh_key
item.description:
```
Delete https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/refresh_key
Header:  
Content-Type:applicaion/json  
Refresh-Key:""  
App-Id:"`application-id>`"  
App-Key:"`application secret key`"
```
Response:
```
{
    "http_code": "200",
    "http_code_desc": "OK",
    "error_code": "API0002",
    "short_message": "OK",
    "long_message": "Request Session terminated successfully.",
    "more_information": ""
}
```

##### To access data from practices user will need an request key. 
✅ Log in to [API portal](https://api.sikkasoft.com). Go to application details & get Application ID and Application Secret Key.

❌ The Application ID and Application Secret Key should not be shared.

item.name: API Field Filtering
item.description:
The default endpoints of the Sikka REST API are designed to be sensible defaults in terms of what data is returned.

Fields parameter provides a single way for modifying all responses for an object. For example, in patients API there are default fields but if your application needs more information, fields parameter allows you to get more fields.

**Important Note about Field Filtering**

The API exposes only default fields on responses. There are some information you will be needed but if it is not included in response then you can get that information using 'fields' parameter. While it's tempting to modify or add fields in responses, this will cause problems with API clients that expect standard responses. This includes things like mobile clients or third party tools.

You may only need a small amount of data, but it's important to keep in mind that the API is about exposing an interface to all clients, not just the feature you're working on.

**What fields parameter does ?**  
Every Sikka API allows to return only default fields. Other fields will not be display in API response. To get more information or fields in response user can use 'fields' parameter.

**How to Use Fields Parameter?**

Sikka API accepts fields as parameters:

In fields parameters users needs to specify which fields API should return in response.

This means that if you specify

``` javascript
https//api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients?fields=firstname,lastname, cell 

 ```

It will return default fields & first name , last name & cell. It will skip / hide other fields.

Examples

``` javascript
URL : https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices

 ```

Response :

``` javascript
{
"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1",
"practice_id": "1",
"name": "Second Site Location",
"address_line1": "12345 Any Street",
"address_line2": "",
"city": "Mt. Vernon",
"state": "IL",
"zipcode": "62864",
"phone": "",
"country": "",
"email": "",
"providers": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/providers/"},
"patients": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/patients/"},
"guarantors": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/guarantors/"},
"appointments": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/appointments/"},
"transactions": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/transactions/"}
}

 ```

If user wants to see “website” in response with other fields

``` javascript
URL : https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices?fields=website

 ```

Response :

``` javascript
{
"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1",
"practice_id": "1",
"name": "Second Site Location",
"address_line1": "12345 Any Street",
"address_line2": "",
"city": "Mt. Vernon",
"state": "IL",
"zipcode": "62864",
"phone": "",
"country": "",
"email": "",
"website":"",
"providers": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/providers/"},
"patients": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/patients/"},
"guarantors": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/guarantors/"},
"appointments": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/appointments/"},
"transactions": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practices/1/transactions/"}
}

 ```

#### How to get the list of all fields?

By default each api returns default fields with necessary information. If you want to get all fields and want to check what other fields are there in api response , use 'get_all' value for 'fields' parameter.  
example :  
get the list of all fields of 'patients' api

``` javascript
URL : https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/patients?fields=get_all

 ```

In response you will get all fields of 'patients' api

#### How to get only fields you want & skip default fields ?

By default each api returns default fields along with fields you want in `fields` parameters. But in a few cases the user wants only the required data without default fields.

In that case users can use `lightweight` parameter. `lightweight` parameter is boolean

**How to Use** `lightweight` **Parameter?**

Set `lightweight = true` & in fields parameters users need to specify which fields API should return in response.

> `lightweight=true` parameter is not recommended to use in `practice_events` api 
  

This means that if you specify

``` javascript
https//api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients?lightweight=true&fields=firstname,lastname,cell 

 ```

It will return first name , last name & cell only.

Response :

``` json
"limit":"1"
"total_count":"27598"
"execution_time":"157"
"pagination":{
"first":"https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients?offset=0&limit=1"
"previous":""
"current":"https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients?offset=0&limit=1"
"next":"https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients?offset=1&limit=1"
"last":"https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients?offset=27597&limit=1"
}
"items":[
{
"firstname":"Hayden"
"lastname":"Johnson"
"cell":"xxx-xxx-xxxx"
}
]
}

 ```

item.name: Pagination
item.description:
Maximum 5000 records fetch available as per Sikka API license. Requests for collections can return between 0 and 5000 results, controlled using the `limit` and `offset` query parameters. All end points are limited to 50 results by default.

`GET /v4/patients?request_key?offset=0&limit=499` Return rows from 0 to 499

The offset should be the page offset (not the item offset). Also, limit will denote page size, along with limit of rows returned.

```
offset = 0 and limit = 500 will return the 1st 500 rows
offset = 1 and limit = 500 will return rows 501 to 1000
offset = 2 and limit = 500 will return rows 1001 to 1500
offset = 3 and limit = 500 will return rows 1501 to 2000

 ```

"pagination" in response:

We have added pagination links in API response. So user can automate the API invocation with hrefs of different pagination links.

``` javascript
[{
"offset": "0",
"limit": "2",
"total_count": "6",
"execution_time": "71",
"pagination": {
"first": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/{api_name}?offset=0&limit=2",
"previous": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/{api_name}?offset=0&limit=2",
"current": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/{api_name}?offset=1&limit=2",
"next": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/{api_name}?offset=2&limit=2",
"last": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/{api_name}?offset=2&limit=2"
},
"items": [{
....
....
....
}]
}]

 ```

When retrieving data from an API with pagination, it's rare to encounter errors while navigating through pages, but if you encounter errors then to handle these errors and retry the same pagination request without starting from scratch, you can follow these steps:

Set up an error handling mechanism: Before making the API request, ensure that you have a way to capture and handle errors. This could involve using try-catch blocks or implementing error handlers provided by the programming language or framework you are using.

Make the initial pagination request: Send the initial request to retrieve the first page of data from the API. Include the necessary parameters for pagination, such as the page number and page size.

Process the response: Once you receive the response from the API, check if it contains the expected data. If the response is successful, proceed with your data processing logic. If the response indicates an error, handle it appropriately based on the error information provided by the API.

Retry on error: If an error occurs while navigating through the pages, you can retry the same pagination request by sending the request again with the same parameters. However, it's important to introduce some mechanism to avoid infinite retries in case of persistent errors. You can set a maximum number of retries or implement an exponential backoff strategy, where you increase the wait time between retries.

Retain state between retries: To retain the same state during retries, you need to store the necessary information from the initial request. This includes the pagination parameters (e.g., page number, page size) and any other relevant context. You can store this information in variables or data structures that persist across retry attempts, such as global variables or session variables.

Retry with updated parameters: If you encounter an error while retrying the pagination request, adjust the necessary parameters before sending the request again. For example, you might need to update the page number to the next page or adjust other parameters based on the error response or the specific requirements of the API.

Handle different types of errors: API errors can vary, so it's essential to handle them accordingly. Some errors might indicate a temporary issue, such as a server overload or a connection problem. In such cases, retrying the request after a brief delay might be sufficient. Other errors could indicate a permanent issue, such as an invalid request or authentication failure. Handle these errors appropriately and consider logging them for further investigation if needed.

By following these steps, you can handle errors while navigating through API pages and retry the pagination request while retaining the same state, allowing you to recover from errors and continue fetching the data you need.

item.name: Rate Limiting
item.description:
#### What is rate limiting?
Most APIs are subject to a limit on how many calls can be made per second (or minute, or other short time period), in order to protect servers from being overloaded and maintain high quality of service to many clients. In the case of Sikka APIs, your plan has an associated rate limit that is tracked and enforced over a second / minute window.

#### What does Sikka API rate limiting look like?
Sikka APIs use HTTP headers to communicate to your application what its rate limit is and how quickly it’s being used. Here’s an example of response header:
```javascript
HTTP/1.1  200  OK
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
X-Rate-Limit-Limit: 5
X-Rate-Limit-Remaining: 3
X-Rate-Limit-Reset: 20
```
- X-Rate-Limit-Limit indicates how many calls your application may make per time window. This time window is 60 seconds, but for the most reliable code you should use the X-Rate-Limit-Reset header.
- X-Rate-Limit-Reset indicates when the current window ends, in seconds from the current time.
- X-Rate-Limit-Remaining indicates how many calls you have remaining in this window.

So in this example, the application has 3 more calls remaining in the next 20 seconds; after that, the counter, X-Rate-Limit-Remaining, will reset back to 5. If the application were to make more calls than allowed, the API will return an `HTTP 429` status code:
```javascript
HTTP/1.1  429  Too  Many  Requests
X-Rate-Limit-Limit: 5
X-Rate-Limit-Remaining: 0
X-Rate-Limit-Reset: 10
```
#### What are some best practices for rate limits?
To make sure your application stays within rate limit always look headers in the API response and use headers to slow down API calls to Sikka API if needed.

For example the set of headers above — we’re allowed 5 calls in 60 seconds so ideally your application should have make 1 api call every 12 seconds. As in the example above , 3 more calls remaining over the next 20 seconds, so your application should make one call every 6 seconds so we get as close as possible to our rate limit without going over.

Divide the reset number by the remaining number to get the spacing we want between calls.

Notice that this approach doesn’t care that other clients may be consuming the same rate limit. For example, a high-volume application may want to have more than one server making queries to Sikka API. Since we recalculate the delay after each request, this approach tracks the correct rate limit even if multiple instances of the client are using the same API key. Hence, for distributed client applications, following these rate limit headers is the easiest way to ensure the application stays under the limits.

**Handle 429**
Even the best rate-limiting code is going to occasionally get an `HTTP 429` error, so make sure your application handles them properly. In a back end application, this probably means slowing down (the example code above should handle this since X-Rate-Limit-Remaining is 0 on 429 responses) and trying again. In a front end application, this probably means showing a nice error message to the user.

**Try to design the usage pattern that makes the fewest calls**
For example, let’s say your application wants to use Sikka API to show extra information about patients in your app. You could make the API call when rendering the patient page

**Consider caching**
Along the same lines, even if your usage pattern demands that you make Sikka API calls at display time, if there’s significant overlap where the same person is displayed more than once, adding a cache between your application and Sikka API could be a big win. Consider using something like [Memcache](http://memcached.org/) and refreshing data from the Sikka API only when it is older then data_insert_date of SPC

item.name: Modified Records

request.description:
'practice_events' api will return changed records in practice between given date range.

In response you will get data with flags (Deleted or Added or Updated). Response also contains changes array. Changes array represents field name , old value and new value.  
example :

``` javascript
    "changes": 
             [
              {
               "field": "transaction_date",
               "old_value": "4/1/2016 12:00:00 AM",
               "new_value": "4/20/2016 12:00:00 AM"
               },
               {
               "field": transaction_entry_date",
               "old_value": "4/1/2016 12:00:00 AM",
               "new_value": "4/20/2016 12:00:00 AM"
               },
               {
                "field": "tooth_from",
                "old_value": "14",
                "new_value": "24"
                }
              ]  

 ```

###### Parameters

###### request_key `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key 
  

###### events`Required`

> Name of the events you want to get modified records. Events name must match with API name 
  

###### loaded_startdate`optional`

> Start date for getting only changed record set. Date format : yyyy-mm-dd or yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ss 
  

###### loaded_enddate`optional`

> End date for getting only changed record set. Date format : yyyy-mm-dd or yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ss 
  

###### interval`optional`

> Value must be integer.  
'interval' parameter allows user to fetch records , which has been changed in last minutes.  
This will be helpful when user does not know loaded_startdate/loaded_enddate and just want to fetch records which has been changed in last minutes (let say 5,10,15.. etc minutes). Maximun value for interval is 1440. You can fetch data which has been changed in last 24 hours (1440 minutes, interval=1440) without specifying loaded_startdate and loaded_enddate.  
**Note : Make sure Sikka platform utility is up and running on client machine. To check when Sikka platform utility (SPU) has refreshed, call 'authorized_practices' and get 'data_insert_date'.** 
  

##### API to find change logs of records :

For example :

- To find patient’s modified records :  
    `https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/patients?request_key={ }&loaded_startdate={}&loaded_enddate={ }`
- To find appointments modified records :  
    `https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/appointments?request_key={ }&loaded_startdate={}&loaded_enddate={ }`
- To find transaction’s modified records :  
    `https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/transactions?request_key={ }&loaded_startdate={}&loaded_enddate={ }`
    

###### In practice_events API

`https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practice_events?request_key={ }&loaded_startdate={}&loaded_enddate={ }&events={name of data you want to retrieve }`

For example , if you want to retrieve patients  
`https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practice_events?request_key={ }&loaded_startdate={}&loaded_enddate={ }&events=patients`

Response :

``` javascript
{
 "offset": "1",
 "limit": "500",
 "total_count": "12",
 "execution_time": "13904",
 "pagination": 
  {
    "first": "[https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practice_events?offset=0&limit=1](https://localhost:44391/v4/practice_events?offset=0&limit=1)",
    "previous": "[https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practice_events?offset=0&limit=1](https://localhost:44391/v4/practice_events?offset=0&limit=1)",
    "current": "[https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/practice_events?offset=1&limit=1](https://localhost:44391/v4/practice_events?offset=1&limit=1)",

   },
  "items": [
            {
            ```response body same as events= api```
            ,"changes": []}]}

 ```

##### When to use practice_events API ?

If you want to get list of modified record using one API

**Recommendations**

- Use it for short time range. like 24 hours or less.
- Response will be slow and data accuracy will be affected if given date range is too big
- Use either interval and flag or loaded_startdate, loaded_enddate and flag combination
- If interval parameter is passed then loaded_startdate and loaded_enddate parameters will not be captured
    

**Limitations** :  
Currently you will be able to get events from

- patients
- appointments
- transactions
- accounts_receivables
- guarantors
- guarantors_v2
- practices
- providers
- treatment_plans
- claims
- claim_descriptions
- prescriptions
- reminders
- lab_panels
    

We will update the list of events as we add in API

item.name: Output Formats
item.description:
The Sikka API handles JSON output formats.
URL, like :

JSON response :
```javascript
GET https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/{api name}
--header request-key: d7ab733c766917fa5ef8ae3a54100620
```
JSON is the default, and will be used if nothing is specified.

item.name: HTTP Compression
item.description:
Sikka API supports HTTP compression of response bodies using standards defined by the HTTP 1.1 specification. Enabling compression is recommended because it reduces bandwidth usage, and time spent retrieving data.

To enable compression, include the following HTTP header in the request:
```javascript
GET /patients HTTP/1.1
Host: www.domain.com
Accept-Encoding: gzip,compress
```
The server understands the compression algorithms from Accept-Encoding and use algorithm to compress the representation before serving it. When successfully compressed, server lets know the client of encoding scheme by another HTTP header i.e. `Content-Encoding`
```javascript
200  OK
Content-Encoding: gzip
```
Compression can save a lot of bandwidth, with very little cost in additional complexity. Also you may know that most web browsers automatically request compressed representations from website host servers – using above headers.
References:
<https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.11>
<https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.3>

item.name: Request Header
item.description:
> ✅ The request header supports 'request-key','app-id' & 'app-key' parameters that are common across all '/v4' endpoints; as a result, the header parameters aren’t documented with each endpoint.

In Sikka API , user can send request key , app id and app key as url parameter also. [ ❌ not recommended for security reason ]

If user does not want to expose keys in url parameter then we do support send keys in request header.


List of request headers:

| Request Header | Description |
| ------ | ------ |
|  `request-key`  | Request-Key header supports in all '/v4' APIs |
|  `app-id`  | App-Id. Application id header supported in all 'v4' api or where it is required |
|  `app-key`  | App-Key. Application Key header supported in all 'v4' api or where it is required |

item.name: Response Header
item.description:
The headers contain a wealth of information that can help you track request and related information. HTTP Headers are an important part of the API request and response as they represent the meta-data associated with the API request and response.
List of response headers:

| Response Header | Description |
| ------ | ------ |
|  `Data-Insert: <completed or in progress>`  | 'data-insert‘ response header let API user know the status of data insert status. User should not fetch data when data insert is in progress. ‘data-insert’ header will help API users to know if data insert is in progress or not. |
|  |  `Data-Insert: completed` - data insert completed, good to fetch data. |
|  |  `Data-Insert: in progress`- data insert is in progress, wait till data insert completed |
|  | APIs has ‘data-insert’ header : transactions , patients , guarantors_v2 , patients_v2 , treatment_plans , appointments , patient_contract_roll_charges |
|  `Request-Key-Expires: <http-date> GMT`  | If 'request_key' is active then 'Request-Key-Expires' value will be request_start_time + 24 hours, if 'request_key' is expired or inactive then request_end_time used as 'Request-Key-Expires'. `http-date format (e.g. Wed, 21 Aug 2019 17:19:33 GMT)`  |
|  | 'Request-Key-Expires' header will be available in all APIs where request_key is used. |

item.name: Webhooks
Payload URL
item.description:
This is your server endpoint that will receive the webhook payload.
For example , you want to received events on
`https://<yourwebsitename>/api/receieve_payload`
Or
`https://<yourwebsitename>/api/payload`

item.name: Content Type
item.description:
At current Sikka Webhooks can be delivered using json format:
The `application/json` content type will deliver the JSON payload directly as the body of the POST.

item.name: Events
item.description:
When configuring a webhook, you can choose which events you would like to receive payloads for. Only subscribing to the specific events you plan on handling is useful for limiting the number of HTTP requests to your server. You can change the list of subscribed events through the UI anytime.
Each event corresponds to a certain set of actions that can happen to practice data or Sikka Platform Cloud.
For example, if you subscribe to the Data Refresh event you'll receive detailed payloads every time when Sikka Practice Utility data refresh completed
To create webhook , log in to [Sikka API portal](https://api.sikkasoft.com). Click on `webhook`. Enter required information and click on `Add Webhook`, it's time to check on your server to test the if events are receiving or not.

The available events are :

| Name | Description |
| ------------- |:-------------|
|  `Data_Refresh`  | This indicates local SPC refresh is completed and data be available via API |
|  `patient`  | When practice chang patient records , new patient added or deleted , this event will trigger. |
|  `transaction`  | When practice chang transaction records , new transaction added or deleted , this event will trigger. |
|  `appointments`  | When practice chang appointments records , new appointments added or deleted , this event will trigger. |

>Note : Sikka Practice Utility has to be up and running on server for all events

item.name: Payloads
item.description:
Each event type has a specific payload format with the relevant event information.
In addition to the fields documented for each event, webhook payloads include the office_id , practice_id on which the event occurred on

item.name: Headers
item.description:
`HTTP POST` payloads that are delivered to your webhook's configured URL endpoint will contain several headers:

Example delivery
```
POST /payload HTTP/1.1
Host: <host>
callback-key: xxxxxxxxx
Content-Type: application/json
Content-Length: 6615
{
BODY
}
```

item.name: Sikka Webhook Retry Policies
item.description:
A retry policy is the process that will take over if/when one of your post back url requests fail .

#### When Do We Retry?

We will retry anytime we do not receive what we consider a successful response from the destination server. Below is a list of HTTP status codes that we consider as successes/failures.

Response Retry
- 200 - success
- 201 - success
- 202 -success
- 204 - success
- 3xx - failure
- 4xx - failure
- 5xx - failure
- Time out - failure

| Attempt | Webhook Notification will be delivered at |
|--|--|
| 0 - This is the initial delivery attempt | Immediately|
| 1 - Delivery failed once, this is the second attempt | failure attempt count =1 |
| 2 - Delivery failed twice, this is the third attempt | failure attempt count = 2 |
| 3 - This is the third attempt | failure attempt count = 3 |
| 4 - This is the fourth attempt | failure attempt count = 4 |
| 5 - This is the fifth attempt | failure attempt count = 5 |
| After 5th failure attempt , webhook status will be inactive and will not send any notification |  |

Webhooks allow you to set up your Apps which subscribe to certain events on practice data or Sikka Platform Cloud. When one of those events is triggered, we'll send a HTTP POST payload to the webhook's configured URL. Webhooks can be used to update your production server or CI builds and let you know about latest activity.

Once webhook configured , the webhook will be triggered each time one or more subscribed events occurs.

You can create up to 2 webhooks for each event on each target

  

>  ![webhook flow](https://api.sikkasoft.com/portal/images/webhook-1.png)

>  ![webhook architechture](https://api.sikkasoft.com/portal/images/webhook-2.png)



Webhooks require a few configuration options before you use of them.

item.name: Resource Query Language (RQL)
item.description:
Data querying is a critical component of the Sikka APIs. With the advance of rich client-driven applications, new querying techniques are needed, and Resource Query Language (RQL) defines a very simple but extensible query language specifically designed to work within URIs and query for collections of resources.

#### Syntax

RQL is specifically designed for the web, using URI friendly delimiters, and using URI character encoding for all text/string values. Syntax makes it easy to use RQL with a variety of existing tools and processes. Please refer to the following sections our documentation for details on supported operators and syntax.

`https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/?find==`

##### Operators

Definition of the common operators supported by Sikka API

###### `=eq_ → equal to`

> Filters for objects where api field values is equal to specified value. Example: 
  

```
GET /patients?find=firstname=eq_joe

```

> The above example will filter all patients with first name equal to joe. 
  

###### `=neq_ → not equal to`

> Filters for objects where api field values is not equal to specified value. Example: 
  

```
GET /patients?find=firstname=neq_joe

```

> The above example will filter all patients with first name not equal to joe. 
  

###### `=like_ → like`

> Filters for objects where api field values like to specified value.  
Example: 
  

```
GET /patients?find=firstname=like_joe

```

> The above example will filter all patients with first name starts with joe. 
  

###### `=gt → greater than ( supports integer & date format )`

> Filters for objects where api field values is greater than specified value.  
Example: 
  

```
GET /patients?find=birthdate=gt_2017-01-01

```

> The above example will filter all patients with birthdate is greater than 2017-01-01. 
  

###### `=gte → greater than equal to ( supports integer & date format )`

> Filters for objects where api field values is greater than equal to specified value.  
Example: 
  

```
GET /patients?find=birthdate=gte_2017-01-01

```

> The above example will filter all patients with birthdate is greater than and equal to 2017-01-01. 
  

###### `=lt → less than ( supports integer & date format )`

> Filters for objects where api field values is less than specified value.  
Example: 
  

```
GET /patients?find=birthdate=lt_2017-01-01

```

> The above example will filter all patients with birthdate is less than 2017-01-01. 
  

###### `=lte → greater than equal to ( supports integer & date format )`

> Filters for objects where api field values is less than equal to specified value.  
Example: 
  

```
GET /patients?find=birthdate=lte_2017-01-01

```

> The above example will filter all patients with birthdate is less than and equal to 2017-01-01. 
  

###### `::OR:: → Logical operators`

> Filters for objects based on logical operator and conditions  
Example:  
Find a patient with patient id = 79 OR guarantor id = 67 
  

```
GET /patients?find=patient_id=eq_79::OR::guarantor_id=eq_67

```

> The above example will filter all patients with patient id 79 or guarantor id 67 
  

###### `::AND:: → Logical operators`

> Filters for objects based on logical operator and conditions  
Example:  
Find a patient with patient id = 79 OR firstname = joe 
  

```
GET /patients?find=patient_id=eq_79::AND::firstname=eq_joe

```

> The above example will filter all patients with patient id 79 and first name 'joe'

item.name: Practice Query Language
item.description: ##### Benefits and Limitations There are many benefits to using dynamic query (PQL) on API endpoints, for both the business and developers. However, there are limitations as well. In order to benefit from getting flexible schemas and result in API response, applications must share responsibility for managing the schema and the integrity of data ###### Benefits - Faster time to market: No learning curve (for developers) & Easy implementation. - Easier development: Build applications and features using simpler queries on Sikka APIs. - Less risk: Tightly integrated with licensing, so there will be no unauthorized access of data points - Limitations - Data models: Complex queries are not supported. Right now, you can join a maximum of 5 APIs in single PQL. - Limited API: Not all APIs are query able. Check API document for API list. ##### Use Cases With dynamic query, APIs can support modern use cases for mission-critical applications, or simplify existing use cases, by combining the flexibility of dynamic query on APIs. - Review Management: Get list of patients visited to practice in one API call. - Finance: Get accounts receivable information of patients and guarantors. - IoT: Devices that need many possible information combinations can use PQL to get dynamic data. - Scheduling: Using PQL get the different combination of appointment scheduling and build app on top of that. ##### List of Sikka API support to PQL You can use below Sikka APIs in PQL - Practices - Transactions - Appointments - Providers - Patients - Guarantors_v2 - Veterinary_patients - Treatment_plans - Claims - Insurance_companies - Accounts_receivables - Payment_plans - Contact_details - Products - Optometry_product_details ##### Architecture ##### Get data from different APIs ‘Practice_query’ (PQL) API allows you to run query on Sikka API and get result. For example: Get the list of patients (with patient & appointment details) who had appointment on ‘2017-05-30’. If you use regular API then you have to call ‘patients’ and ‘appointments’ API. Using ‘practice_query’ (PQL), get data and merge it on client side ##### How to use ‘PQL’ in Sikka API testing tool ###### Response:

item.name: Migrating v2 to v4 ?
item.description:
| Features | v2 | v4 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Base url | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2) | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4) |
| Auth url | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/auth/v2](https://api.sikkasoft.com/auth/v2) | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4) |
| API field filtering | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Expanding object | 🗸 | ⨯ |
| Pagination | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Rate limiting | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Modified records | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Practice events | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Output format | /json ( Default )/xml | json |
| HTTP compression | Accept-Encoding: gzip,compress | Accept-Encoding: gzip,compress |
| Error codes | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Request header | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Response header | 🗸 | 🗸 ( with more info. headers) |
| Request key | In query parameter : request_key In request header : Request-Key | (Not recommended) In query parameter : request_key (Recommended) In request header : Request-Key |
| Webhooks | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Practice Query language ( PQL ) | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Date format | YYYY-MM-DD , YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS | YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS |
| Query functions | AND | AND,OR,LIKE,GREATER THAN,LESS THAN,EQUAL TO,NOT EQUAL TO |
| Query filter syntax | & | \- find=`api field name`\=eq_`value` , =eq_ → equal to , =neq_ → not equal to , =like_ → like , =gt → greater than ( supports int & date ) , =gte → greater than equal to ( supports int & date ) , =lt → less than ( supports int & date ) , =lte → less than equal to ( supports int & date ) , find=patient_id=eq_23::OR::guarantor_id=neq_45 , find=patient_id=eq_23::AND::amount=gt_45 |
|  |  |  |
| Response body | All fields by default | In v4 , by default few api fields will be return and if user wants more fields then it can be fetched by “field” parameters. This feature has been implemented to improve api response time & return only necessary fields in API response. |
|  |  |  |
| Query parameters | predefined | Result will be filtered by any fields returned in API response |
| HATEOAS ( hrefs ) | 🗸 | 🗸 |
| Generate request key | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/start?app_id=app_id&app_key=app_key&office_id=office_id&secret_key=secret_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/start?app_id=app_id&app_key=app_key&office_id=office_id&secret_key=secret_key) | POST [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key) |
| Generate request key using refresh key | ⨯ | POST [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key) |
| Delete refresh key | DELETE [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/refresh_token/{refresh_token}?client_id={client_id}&client_secret={client_secret}](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/refresh_token/%7Brefresh_token%7D?client_id=%7Bclient_id%7D&client_secret=%7Bclient_secret%7D) | DELETE [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/refresh_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/refresh_key) -Header refresh-key:"" app-id:"" app-key:"" |
| End API | [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/end?request_key={request_key}](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/end?request_key=%7Brequest_key%7D) | DELETE [https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key](https://api.sikkasoft.com/v4/request_key) -Header Request-Key:"" |

request.description:
The ‘data_sync_status’ api indicates if the practice management system integration is uptodate. ‘Status’ in api response should be equal to ‘refresh’ to make sure data you are receiving via api is correct.

> The ‘data_sync_status’ api resource returns the real time status of practice management system connection.

> **"Status":"not_refresh"** - Sikka integration is not able to connect practice management systems for more than 24 hours.

> **"Status":"refresh"** - Sikka integration is connected practice management systems & data is up to date. Check data_insert_date for latest data fetch.

> **“Interval”** parameter allows you to get the list of practices refreshed in the last 5, 10, 15… minutes.

Sample output

| Status | Office_id | practice_name | data_insert_date |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| refresh | D1000 | ProForm Clinics | 2022-08-02T18:12:59 |
| refresh | D12435 | Fountain Valley Physical Medicine Center | 2022-07-29T02:34:16 |
| not refresh | C10001 | The Brain Center | 2021-06-09T23:31:07 |

###### Parameters

###### **app-id** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### **app-key** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### **office_id** `optional`

> Office_id you received from ‘authorized_practices’ API

###### **interval** `optional (int)`

> Value must be integer.  
> 'interval' parameter allows the user to get the list of practices which have been refreshed in the last minutes.

Get all practice details for authorized office id and return with access is on or off.

###### Headers

###### **App-Id** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### **App-Key** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### Parameters

###### **office_id** `Required`

> Office_id you received from ‘authorized_practices’ API

POST ‘practice_location’ API allows to turn on and off API access for listed practice location(s). Users need to pass practice ids (in case of multiple practice ids, that should be separated by comma) which they want to turn on or off.

###### Headers

###### **App-Id** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### **App-Key** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### Request Body

###### **office_id** `Required`

> Office_id you received from ‘authorized_practices’ API

###### **practice_id** `Required`

> practice_id you received from practices or practice_location API.

###### **access** `Required`

> access. Value must be ON or OFF.

POST ‘remote_command’ API allows to send command to 'Sikka Practice Utility' to refresh data and change refresh settings.

###### Headers

###### **App-Id** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key 
  

###### **App-Key** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key 
  

###### Request Body

###### **office_id** `Required`

> Office_id you received from ‘authorized_practices’ API 
  

###### **spc_id** `Required`

> spc_id you received from health_check API. 
  

###### **command_name** `Required`

> command_name. Value should be refresh_data, change_setting_schedule_interval or change_setting_schedule_time. 
  

###### **interval_type** `Optional`

> interval_type is mandatory if command_name is change_setting_schedule_interval. Value should be Minutes or Hours. 
  

###### **interval_length** `Optional`

> interval_length is mandatory if command_name is change_setting_schedule_interval. if interval_type is Hours then value should be between 1 to 24. if interval_type is Minutes then value should be between 15 to 60. 
  

###### **new_value** `Optional`

> new_value is mandatory if command_name is change_setting_schedule_time. Value should be time in hh:mm tt format.

Get remote command status.

###### Headers

###### **App-Id** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key 
  

###### **App-Key** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key 
  

###### Parameters

###### **id** `Required`

> You received in ‘POST remote_command’ API response.

‘health_check’ API provides detailed information about SPC and machine, SPC is installed on. 

It contains error log information, PMS, machine, SPC and data synchronization dates

###### Headers

###### **App-Id** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### **App-Key** `Required`

> A Valid 32 characters alpha-numeric request key

###### Parameters

###### **office_id** `optional`

> Mastercustomerid, This is the ID assigned to a practice when that practice is added

###### **practice_id** `optional`

> practice id of office

###### **spc_id** `optional`

> spc_id

###### **spc_version** `optional`

> spc_version

###### **practice_management_system** `optional`

> practice_management_system

###### **practice_management_system_version** `optional`

> practice_management_system_version

###### **spc_schedule_type** `optional`

> spc_schedule_type

###### **web_upload_error_priority** `optional`

> web_upload_error_priority

###### **domain** `optional`

> domain

###### **spc_error_priority** `optional`

> spc_error_priority

###### **spc_error_flag** `optional`

> spc_error_flag

###### **etl_version** `optional`

> etl_version

###### **is_inactive** `optional`

> is_inactive 

##### API response contains below information 

| SPC information      |  |  |
| ----------- | ----------- |---------|
| office_id  | spc_id       | practice_id
| refresh_time   | spc_version        | spc_schedule_time
| spc_schedule_type   | spc_schedule_interval        | is_spc_update_locked
| spc_update_lock_note   | last_spc_updated_checked        | is_delta_import_enable
| domain   | spc_error_flag        | spc_error_priority
| spc_error_description   | timezone        | is_inactive


| ETL information     |       |  |
|---------------------|----------------------------------|----------------------------------|
| etl_start           | etl_error_priority               | local_insert_error_priority      |
| etl_end             | etl_error_description            | local_insert_cpu_utilization     |
| web_upload_start    | etl_cpu_utilization              | local_insert_memory_utilization  |
| web_upload_end      | etl_memory_utilization           | local_upload_error_description   |
|  | financial_error_priority         | web_upload_error_flag            |
|    | financial_error_description      | web_upload_error_priority        |
| financial_etl_start | financial_etl_cpu_utilization    | web_upload_bandwidth_utilization |
| financial_etl_end   | financial_etl_memory_utilization | web_upload_error_description     |
| etl_error_log       | local_insert_error_log           | upload_to_server                 |
| upload_to_client    |                 |                  |
| etl_version         |                       |                       |


| PMS information                                         |
|---------------------------------------------|
| practice_management_system                  |
| practice_management_system_version          |
| practice_management_system_version_detected |
| practice_management_system_data_path        |
| DetectedPMSVersion                          |
| PMSDataPath                                 |
| PMSDatabaseName                             |


| Financial System Information                                      |
|----------------------------------------------|
| financial_management_system                  |
| financial_management_system_version          |
| financial_management_system_version_detected |
| financial_management_system_data_path        |


| Teamviwer         |
|-------------------|
| teamviwer_id      |
| teamviwer_version |



##### When you should use ‘health_check’ API ?

>  If you want to build SPC support portal and monitor SPC & ETL health.
    
>  Check SPC information. SPC should be active , there should be no error & refresh time should be current ( based on SPC schedule type setting )
    
>  In case of error or data is not updated , first check SPC_error_flag , spc_error_description
    
>  For more details you can check ETL information & PMS information ( start & end time , error description , notes , priority etc. )


For example, report SPC error codes and descriptions that will direct you to the cause. It may indicate that the PMS Version detected seems to be different from what is configured. Or it will tell you the last time we heard from that SPC, or what version it is, how much of the cpu is being used for the refresh, how much memory there is, the version of the OS, it’s IP addresses and more.

item.name: Quickstart
item.description:
In this guide we will walk you through all necessary steps to start accessing data from practice.

1.Authorized practices:

This API will give you the list of practices from which you can access data

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/auth/v2/authorized_practices?app_id={your application id}&app_key={ your application key }

```

*   Returns 'office_id' and 'secret_key'
    

2.Start call to get Request Key for practices:

In response of ‘authorized_practices’ API you have ‘office_id’ and ‘secret_key’. Use it in ‘start’ API

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/start?app_id={your application id}&app_key={ your application key }&office_id={office_id}&secret_key={secret_key}

```

*   Returns Request Key: i.e '52457c9dhgfttfk88798793a4c7e4fa54902'
    

3.Patients API call:

API to get the list of patients

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/patients?request_key={request_key}

```

For veterinary hospitals use ‘veterinary_patients’ API to get the list of pets

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/patients/veterinary_patients?request_key={request_key}

```

After step 3

4.Pet Owners call:

API to get the list of pet owners

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/guarantors?request_key={request_key}&offset=0&limit=10

```

For more information about a particular endpoint, go to API v2.0 documentation. You will be taken to the API’s documentation page, which includes what query parameters the API will accept, what the JSON or XML parameters will be in the response, and an example.

item.name: API Field Filtering
item.description:
The default endpoints of the Sikka REST API are designed to be sensible defaults in terms of what data is returned.  
Fields parameter provides a single way for modifying all responses for an object. For example, in patients API there are around 50 fields but your application needs only 5 of them, Fields parameter allows you to get only 5 fields.

**Important Note about Field Filtering**

The API exposes many fields on API responses, including things you might not need, or might not fit into how your application works. While it's tempting to modify or remove fields from responses, this will cause problems with API clients that expect standard responses. This includes things like mobile clients or third party tools.  
You may only need a small amount of data, but it's important to keep in mind that the API is about exposing an interface to all clients, not just the feature you're working on.

**What fields Parameter Does**

In every Sikka API fields parameter allows to return only requested fields. Other fields will not be display in API response. Please note that there are certain fields which user can not remove from API response. Those are the mandatory fields. To get the whole list of mandatory fields please contact Sikka API team

**How to Use Fields Parameter**

Sikka API accepts fields as parameters:  
In fields parameters users needs to specify which fields API should return in response.  
This means that if you specify

``` javascript
https//api.sikkasoft.com/v2/patients?request_key={ }&fields= firstname,lastname, cell ```
It will return only first name , last name ,cell & mandatory fields only. It will skip / hide other fields.
Examples
```javascript
URL : https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices?request_key={valid request key}

```

Response :

``` javascript
{
"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1",
"practice_id": "1",
"name": "Second Site Location",
"address_line1": "12345 Any Street",
"address_line2": "",
"city": "Mt. Vernon",
"state": "IL",
"zipcode": "62864",
"phone": "",
"country": "",
"email": "",
"website": "",
"providers": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/providers/"},
"patients": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/patients/"},
"guarantors": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/guarantors/"},
"appointments": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/appointments/"},
"transactions": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/transactions/"}
}

```

Now if user wants to see only “name” in response and skip other fields

``` javascript
URL : https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices?request_key={valid request key}&fields=name

```

Response :

``` javascript
{
"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1",
"practice_id": "1",
"name": "Second Site Location",
"providers": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/providers/"},
"patients": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/patients/"},
"guarantors": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/guarantors/"},
"appointments": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/appointments/"},
"transactions": {"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/transactions/"}
}

```

item.name: Expanding Objects
item.description:
Many objects contain the ID of a related object in their response properties. For example, a patient may have an associated practice id, guarantor id, provider d. Those objects can be expanded in line with the expand request parameter. Objects that can be expanded are noted in this documentation. This parameter is available on all API requests, and applies to the response of that request only, and will work when single object is in response only.  
You can nest expand requests with the expand parameter. For example, requesting "expand=practice" on a patient will expand the patient object with practice object. Response will be patient API response, including practice object.  
You can expand multiple objects at once by identifying multiple items in the expand parameter, separated by comma (",").

Request :

``` javascript
URL : https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/patients/76?request_key={valid request key}&expand=practice

```

Response :

``` javascript
{
"href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/patients/76",
"patient_id": "76",
"guarantor_id": "76",
"firstname": "Kvana",
"middlename": "",
"lastname": "Aws4",
.....
"practice_id": "1",
        "practice": {
        "href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1",
        "practice_id": "1",
        "name": "Test Dental",
        "address_line1": "",
        "address_line2": "",
        "city": "San Jose",
        "state": "CA",
        "zipcode": "95110",
        "phone": "xxx-xxx-xxxx",
        "country": "",
        "email": "",
        "website": "",
        "description": "",
        "providers": {
        "href": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/practices/1/providers/"
        },
"hygienist": ""
}

```

item.name: Pagination
item.description:
Maximum 5000 records fetch available as per Sikka API license. Requests for collections can return between 0 and 5000 results, controlled using the `limit` and `offset` query parameters. All end points are limited to 500 results by default.

`GET /v2/patients?request_key={request_key}&offset=0&limit=499` Return rows from 0 to 499

The offset should be the page offset (not the item offset). Also, limit will denote page size, along with limit of rows returned.

```
 offset = 0 and limit = 500 will return the 1st 500 rows
offset = 1 and limit = 500 will return rows 501 to 1000
offset = 2 and limit = 500 will return rows 1001 to 1500
offset = 3 and limit = 500 will return rows 1501 to 2000

 ```

"pagination" in response:  
We have added pagination links in API response. So user can automate the API invocation with hrefs of different pagination links.

``` javascript
[{
    "offset": "0",
    "limit": "2",
    "total_count": "6",
    "execution_time": "71",
    "pagination": {
        "first": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api_name}?offset=0&limit=2",
        "previous": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api_name}?offset=0&limit=2",
        "current": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api_name}?offset=1&limit=2",
        "next": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api_name}?offset=2&limit=2",
        "last": "https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api_name}?offset=2&limit=2"
    },
    "items": [{
....
....
....
    }]
}]

 ```

When retrieving data from an API with pagination, it's rare to encounter errors while navigating through pages, but if you encounter errors then to handle these errors and retry the same pagination request without starting from scratch, you can follow these steps:

Set up an error handling mechanism: Before making the API request, ensure that you have a way to capture and handle errors. This could involve using try-catch blocks or implementing error handlers provided by the programming language or framework you are using.

Make the initial pagination request: Send the initial request to retrieve the first page of data from the API. Include the necessary parameters for pagination, such as the page number and page size.

Process the response: Once you receive the response from the API, check if it contains the expected data. If the response is successful, proceed with your data processing logic. If the response indicates an error, handle it appropriately based on the error information provided by the API.

Retry on error: If an error occurs while navigating through the pages, you can retry the same pagination request by sending the request again with the same parameters. However, it's important to introduce some mechanism to avoid infinite retries in case of persistent errors. You can set a maximum number of retries or implement an exponential backoff strategy, where you increase the wait time between retries.

Retain state between retries: To retain the same state during retries, you need to store the necessary information from the initial request. This includes the pagination parameters (e.g., page number, page size) and any other relevant context. You can store this information in variables or data structures that persist across retry attempts, such as global variables or session variables.

Retry with updated parameters: If you encounter an error while retrying the pagination request, adjust the necessary parameters before sending the request again. For example, you might need to update the page number to the next page or adjust other parameters based on the error response or the specific requirements of the API.

Handle different types of errors: API errors can vary, so it's essential to handle them accordingly. Some errors might indicate a temporary issue, such as a server overload or a connection problem. In such cases, retrying the request after a brief delay might be sufficient. Other errors could indicate a permanent issue, such as an invalid request or authentication failure. Handle these errors appropriately and consider logging them for further investigation if needed.

By following these steps, you can handle errors while navigating through API pages and retry the pagination request while retaining the same state, allowing you to recover from errors and continue fetching the data you need.

item.name: Rate Limiting
item.description:
#### What is rate limiting?

Most APIs are subject to a limit on how many calls can be made per second (or minute, or other short time period), in order to protect servers from being overloaded and maintain high quality of service to many clients. In the case of Sikka APIs, your plan has an associated rate limit that is tracked and enforced over a second / minute window.

#### What does Sikka API rate limiting look like?

Sikka APIs use HTTP headers to communicate to your application what its rate limit is and how quickly it’s being used. Here’s an example of response header:

``` javascript
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
X-Rate-Limit-Limit: 5
X-Rate-Limit-Remaining: 3
X-Rate-Limit-Reset: 20

```

*   X-Rate-Limit-Limit indicates how many calls your application may make per time window. This time window is 60 seconds, but for the most reliable code you should use the X-Rate-Limit-Reset header.
*   X-Rate-Limit-Reset indicates when the current window ends, in seconds from the current time.
*   X-Rate-Limit-Remaining indicates how many calls you have remaining in this window.
    So in this example, the application has 3 more calls remaining in the next 20 seconds; after that, the counter, X-Rate-Limit-Remaining, will reset back to 5. If the application were to make more calls than allowed, the API will return an `HTTP 429` status code:
    

``` javascript
HTTP/1.1 429 Too Many Requests
X-Rate-Limit-Limit: 5
X-Rate-Limit-Remaining: 0
X-Rate-Limit-Reset: 10

```

#### What are some best practices for rate limits?

To make sure your application stays within rate limit always look headers in the API response and use headers to slow down API calls to Sikka API if needed.

For example the set of headers above — we’re allowed 5 calls in 60 seconds so ideally your application should have make 1 api call every 12 seconds. As in the example above , 3 more calls remaining over the next 20 seconds, so your application should make one call every 6 seconds so we get as close as possible to our rate limit without going over.

Divide the reset number by the remaining number to get the spacing we want between calls.

Notice that this approach doesn’t care that other clients may be consuming the same rate limit. For example, a high-volume application may want to have more than one server making queries to Sikka API. Since we recalculate the delay after each request, this approach tracks the correct rate limit even if multiple instances of the client are using the same API key. Hence, for distributed client applications, following these rate limit headers is the easiest way to ensure the application stays under the limits.

**Handle 429**

Even the best rate-limiting code is going to occasionally get an `HTTP 429` error, so make sure your application handles them properly. In a back end application, this probably means slowing down (the example code above should handle this since X-Rate-Limit-Remaining is 0 on 429 responses) and trying again. In a front end application, this probably means showing a nice error message to the user.

**Try to design the usage pattern that makes the fewest calls**

For example, let’s say your application wants to use Sikka API to show extra information about patients in your app. You could make the API call when rendering the patient page

**Consider caching**

Along the same lines, even if your usage pattern demands that you make Sikka API calls at display time, if there’s significant overlap where the same person is displayed more than once, adding a cache between your application and Sikka API could be a big win. Consider using something like [Memcache](http://memcached.org/) and refreshing data from the Sikka API only when it is older then data_insert_date of SPC

item.name: Output Formats
item.description:
The Sikka API handles multiple output formats. Currently, the only supported formats are JSON and XML Output formats are selected with a specifier that is appended to the URL, like :

JSON response :

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api name}/json?request_key={ }

```

XML response :

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api name}/xml?request_key={ }

```

Default response :

``` javascript
https://api.sikkasoft.com/v2/{api name}?request_key={ }

```

JSON is the default, and will be used if nothing is specified.

item.name: HTTP Compression
item.description:
Sikka API supports HTTP compression of response bodies using standards defined by the HTTP 1.1 specification. Enabling compression is recommended because it reduces bandwidth usage, and time spent retrieving data.

To enable compression, include the following HTTP header in the request:

``` javascript
GET        /patients         HTTP/1.1
Host:     www.domain.com
Accept-Encoding:     gzip,compress

```

The server understands the compression algorithms from Accept-Encoding and use algorithm to compress the representation before serving it. When successfully compressed, server lets know the client of encoding scheme by another HTTP header i.e. `Content-Encoding`

``` javascript
200 OK
Content-Encoding:     gzip

```

Compression can save a lot of bandwidth, with very little cost in additional complexity. Also you may know that most web browsers automatically request compressed representations from website host servers – using above headers.

References:

[https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.11](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.11)  
[https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.3](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.3)
